foreground.title: Ireland's Fabulous Fens
foreground.subtitle:
A story map
introducing you to the different fen types in Ireland and their ecology, with information on where to visit sites around the country. A story map based on information held in the Map
of Irish Wetlands.

text.value: At Wetland Surveys Ireland and Foss Environmental Consulting we have been surveying, studying and researching fens throughout Ireland since 2000 and would like to share some of our fascination for these wonderful Irish wetlands with you in this story map.

Fens are magical places and a unique part of the Irish landscape. They help regulate and clean our water supply, support a rich variety of wild plants and animals, have a significant economic value, and can even tell us about our past history.
With so much in their favour, it is surprising that fens are one of the least studied Irish habitats, and a part of our landscape that most people are unaware of and understand little about.

foreground.title: Here are a few facts about Irish fens

text.value: • Ireland is rich in fen sites, the Map of Irish Wetlands has identified 1,700 sites nationally
• Fens occur throughout Ireland
• They occur in a variety of landscape settings
• Many sites with the name "Bog" in the title, such as Scragh Bog in Co. Westmeath are actually fens
• There are six main Irish fen types found in Ireland
• Four of these fen types are protected as Annex 1 habitats under the EU Habitats Directive
• Ireland’s fens remain critically understudied
• No national inventory of Irish fens exists so their national distribution remains unclear
• Irish fens are primarily threatened by land reclamation, drainage and infilling
• According to Irish Peatland Conservation Council there has been a 77% loss of fen habitat in Ireland
• Many fens are in an unfavourable state of conservation in Ireland

A fen is a peat forming wetland system with a permanently high water level at or just below its surface. It’s principal source of nutrients is from surface or groundwater and the substrate is an alkaline to slightly acidic peat soil. The vegetation of fens is diverse and usually dominated by sedges (grass like plants) and brown mosses.
The photograph shows Saw sedge (Cladium mariscus) fen at Ballaghan and Whitestown, Co. Louth.
Fens differ from bogs because they are less acidic and have relatively higher mineral levels. They are therefore able to support a much more diverse community of plants and animals.
The photograph shows species rich transition mire at Crumlin Lough, Co. Monaghan.

Fens occur in a variety of situations from sea level up into the mountains in valleys or depressions, valley head fens, within tall reed beds, on the landward side of hard-water oligotrophic lakeshore communities, calcium-rich flush areas in blanket bogs, dune slack areas, fens adjacent to raised and blanket bogs, in turlough sites, depressions in limestone pavement and wet hollows in machair, and spring fed habitats including cliffs, and even saltmarsh.
The photograph shows transition mire in valley setting at Rootate, Co. Louth.
Fens also developed on areas with a history of extensive peat extraction in past centuries, and these secondary fens are common around Ireland.
The photograph shows secondary fen community which has developed on cutaway bog at Drumgallan, Co. Monaghan.

foreground.title: Why should we care about Ireland's fens ?

text.value: • Fens are often intimately associated with freshwater bodies
• Fens act in a number of ways to regulate the environment
• Fen functions include water purification, flood prevention and carbon storage
• Like bogs, the peat in fens contains a very informative record of the past
• Fens have been used by humanity throughout history and have religious, historical or archeological value
• Fens have a high nature conservation value
• There is a great diversity of plants and animals that inhabit fens
• Fens are important breeding sites and feeding areas for birds
• Fens have a significant economic value for sporting, recreation and fishing
Fens may be subdivided into two major groups based upon their setting within the landscape and their hydrology or water supply. These are topogenous fens and soligenous fens.
The photograph shows Saw sedge (Cladium mariscus) fen at Summerhill Lough, Co. Monaghan.
Topogenous fens

These fens form within basins in the landscape where the water fluctuations are in a vertical direction. Water accumulates on account of the topography or the physical shape of the landscape, including its hills, valleys, and rivers.
There are 3 types of topogenous fens.
The photograph shows Carex diandra transition mire surrounding the open water at Lough Bane pNHA Co. Westmeath.

1. Open water transition fens are those that occur on lake edges such as the Saw sedge fens around Lough Corrib, Co. Galway shown in the photograph. These fens occur predominantly in the limestone regions of Ireland and can be quite extensive.

2. Flood plain fens occur on the waterlogged floodplain of rivers or streams such as those alongside the River Shannon and its tributaries. This fen type is now rare in Ireland, as many sites have disappeared as a result of arterial drainage and agricultural reclamation.

3. Basin fens form in waterlogged basins in the landscape such as Scragh Bog, Co. Westmeath. This fen type is rare in Ireland. With time many basin fens have developed into raised bogs as the peat continued to accumulate. The basin fens that remain are important refugia for a number of rare plants and animals.
Soligenous fens

The second major fen type are soligenous fens which form where sloping terrain provides a continuous supply of flowing water, such as in the many flushes found in for example the Sheeffrey Hills in Co. Mayo shown in the photograph. Here the horizontal movement of water is more important than the vertical movement of water.

1. Valley fens develop on the floor of shallow valleys. The slope within these fens may be very gentle and water movement may not be immediately apparent. Pollardstown Fen Co. Kildare is the most widely known valley fen in Ireland. Valley fens are rare and occur mainly in the eastern part of the country.

2. Flush fens tend to be small areas of fen within other larger wetland types, mainly blanket bog. Within these areas the localised flow of water supplies more minerals than are found in the surrounding peatland resulting in the formation of  fen. This fen type is widespread within blanket bog and upland areas of Ireland such as the Wicklow Mountains in Co. Dublin and Wicklow. Unusual communities of plants may be found in these fens, more typical of arctic conditions.

3. Calcareous Spring fens develop around freshwater springs that are especially rich in calcium. The water feeding these fens wells up from the ground and deposits a white crust known as tufa on the ground as well as on plants and mosses. They are usually very small sites and often occur within larger wetland system, on cliffs and along the coast such as at Loughshinny Co. Dublin. These fens are rare in Ireland.

image.caption: Tufa spring cascade in wet willow woodland at Ballyman Glen, Co. Wicklow.

text.value: Fens can also be classified on their water chemistry and floristics (plants that occur there), into rich fens and poor fens. The main difference in vegetation types that occur on fens depends primarily on whether the fen is described as a “rich” (basic water chemistry with calcium present) or “poor” (acid water chemistry) fen. Although two fen categories are recognised, in effect these two types may grade gradually from one type into the other depending on water supply and location.
The photograph shows Blunt-flowered Rush (Juncus subnodulosus) rich fen community at Lisnarawer Fen Co. Sligo.

Rich fens and flushes are fed by water that is base-rich or calcareous, and are mainly found in areas overlying limestone. The peat substrate is alkaline. Blunt flowered rush (Juncus subnodulosus) and Black Bog Rush (Schoenus nigricans)  are indicator species in the vegetation of rich fens.
The main photograph shows an area of  Black Bog Rush rich fen at Carney Commons Co. Tipperary.

image.caption: Rich fen with Black bog rush and Blunt flowered rush at Lisnarawer Co. Sligo.

text.value: Poor fens and flushes are fed by water that is base poor or acid, but not as acidic as raised or blanket bogs. The underlying substrate consists of acid peat. Sedges (grass like plants) such as Star sedge (Carex echinata) is an indicator species in the vegetation of poor fens.
The main photograph shows area of poor fen dominated by Bottle sedge (Carex rostrata) at Carroward Co. Sligo.

image.caption: Appearance of poor fen community with Bog Bean and Sphagnum moss at Lisarilly, Co. Monaghan.

text.value: Between these extremes are the transition mire or quaking fens, which tend to occur in areas with a chemistry that is between base rich and base poor. Lesser tussock sedge (Carex diandra) is an indicator species in the vegetation of transition or quaking fens.
The main photograph shows a transition mire at Castlecarragh Co. Louth with a variety of sedge and grass species and scattered Reedmace (Typha latifola).

image.caption: Transition mire vegetation with Many-headed bog cotton and Water Horsetail on Crumlin Lough Co. Monaghan.

text.value: A fen is often a mosaic of different habitats ranging from open-water, reed-beds, small sedge vegetation, to semi-terrestrial birch and alder woodland or bogs. The complex of habitats that can occur within a fen contributes to the rich diversity of life (biodiversity) that has been recorded on Ireland's fens.
Fens have an incredibly high biodiversity of plants and wildlife. Up to 1,000 species have been recorded in fens. 25 of Ireland’s most endangered rare plants and animals survive only in fens.
Main photograph shows species rich alkaline fen at Ballynafid Lake and Fen, Co. Westmeath.

Fen plants grow in water or need a waterlogged environment. They include a large variety of trees, shrubs, herbs, grasses, sedges, ferns, mosses and algae. Many of these species have special adaptations to allow then to live in the waterlogged environment found in wetlands. Shallow roots or hollow stems facilitate survival of the root system during times of waterlogging and low oxygen levels. These adaptations also enable plants to grow in extremely wet acid or alkaline habitats.
The photograph shows Lesser tussock-sedge (Carex diandra) on Corlea Fen Co. Monaghan.

Typically fens look grassy. The main species that give fens this appearance are a variety of fen sedges and grasses including such species as Black bog rush, Carnation sedge, Bottle sedge, Lesser tussock-sedge, Blunt flowered rush, Common reed, Bulrush, Purple moor-grass and Saw sedge.
The main photograph show Saw sedge (Cladium mariscus) on Summerhill Lough fen Co. Monaghan.

image.caption: Black bog rush (Schoenus nigricans) dominated vegetation at Scragh Bog Co. Westmeath.

text.value: Fens are also important habitats for a number of native Irish orchids species. Species that are characteristic on fens include such species as Early marsh orchid, Fly orchid and Board-leaved helleborine.
The main photograph show the Frog Orchid (Coeloglossum viride) on Lackagh fen Co. Sligo.

image.caption: Broad-leaved helleborine (Epipactis palustris) on Ballynafid fen Co. Westmeath.

text.value: Mosses and liverworts also form an important part of a fens biodiversity. Brown mosses such as Scorpidium scorpioides, Drepanocladus revolvens, Campylium stellatum and Calliergonella cuspidata occur in rich fens, while certain Sphagnum or Bog Moss species may become dominant in poor fens.
The main photograph shows an alkaline brown moss community from secondary alkaline fen at Derrinclare Co. Offaly.

image.caption: Perhaps the commonest fen moss, Calliergonella cuspidata in calcareous spring in the Glenasmole valley Co. Dublin.
The liverwort Conocephalum conicum growing in calcareous springs at Ballyman Glen Co. Dublin.

text.value: A host of other plants occur in Irish fens including, Grass of Parnassus, Purple loosestrife, Devil’s-bit-scabious, Water mint and Fen thistle to mention just a few.
The main photograph shows Marsh St. John's-wort (Hypericum elodes) and purple coloured Water Mint (Mentha aquatica) in poor fen at Cornaglare Co. Monaghan.

image.caption: Marsh cinquefoil (Comarum palustre) a stunning spring flower found on many fens.
Fen thistle (Cirsium dissectum) found in many rich fens.
Grass of Parnassus (Parnassia palustris) one of the species found on calcareous fens.
Purple loosestrife (Lythrum salicaria) one of the characteristic species adding a splash of colour to fens in late summer.

text.value: Over 600 different animal species have been recorded on fens in Ireland. The vast majority of these animals are invertebrates such as beetles, flies, spiders and other insects including damselflies, dragonflies, and a variety of moth and butterflies and snails. Other animals that inhabit fens include frogs, newts and a variety of mammals including pygmy shrews, otters and various bats.
The Common Frog (Rana temporaria) our most abundant and widespread amphibian found in the majority of fens around Ireland.
The Smooth Newt (Lissotriton vulgaris) is an amphibian found in fens and wetlands, here in poor fen at Lough Nahinch Co. Monaghan.

Fens provide breeding sites and feeding areas for a wide variety of birds. On Pollardstown fen twenty-seven different species of bird have been found breeding on or in the immediate vicinity of the fen.
The reed beds are ideal breeding habitats for birds such as Little grebe, Crested grebe, Mute swan, Teal, Mallard, Water rail, Moorhen, Coot, Sedge warbler and Reed bunting.

image.caption: Coot nest (Fulica atra) among the reeds.

text.value: Main photograph shows Coot with recently hatched chicks. Coots use reedbed areas to nest in and as a nursery ground for young chicks.

image.caption: Grey Heron (Ardea cinerea) on of the wetland birds found in fens where it feeds on frogs, fish and invertebrates.
Meadow Pipit (Anthus pratensis) a species which lives in and around fens feeding on the rich insect life found there.

text.value: Temporary lakes forming in the floodplain fens or callows between Athlone and Portumna which includes the lower portions of the River Suck and little Brosna are important refugia for over wintering wildfowl such as Whooper swans, Greenland white-fronted geese, Widgeon, Golden plover, and Godwit.
Whooper swans now tend to feed on grasslands and stubble fields on lowland open farmland around inland fens and wetlands.

Fens are home to a vast array on invertebrates or creepy crawlies. One of the most impressive is the Raft spider (Dolomedes fimbriatus) , an aquatic spider found in fens and small ponds, that can walk on water and feeds on aquatic invertebrates, tadpoles and even small fish.

image.caption: Female Dolomedes fimbriatus spider carrying an egg case.

text.value: Beautiful Damoiselle (Calopteryx virgo), a type of damselfly found along slow flowing ditches or streams in fens and wetlands. They are territorial species and excellent hunters.
Dragonflies are important carnivore of fens. The main photograph shows Hawker dragonfly (Aeshna juncea) female laying eggs in poor fen pool at Ballinvariscal, Co. Kerry.

image.caption: Four spotted chaser (Libellula quadrimaculata) dragonfly, a species of dragonfly frequently recorded from poor fen and transition mire sites.

text.value: Fens also provide a home for a large range of flies and beetles  that feed on fen plants.
The main photograph shows the Club Horned Sawfly (Abia sericea) on its food plant Devils Bit Scabious at Clarderry Co. Monaghan, a common plant of fen and wetland habitats.

image.caption: The striking saw fly larva (Athalia scutellariae) from Rockmarshall fen in Co. Louth.

text.value: A rare butterfly of particular note, which breeds on fens, is the Marsh Fritillary (Euphydryas aurinia). Its caterpillars feed exclusively on Devils bit scabious (Succisa pratensis). The Marsh Fritillary is now protected in Ireland and Europe under the EU Habitats Directive.

image.caption: Marsh Fritillary caterpillars live in groups during the autumn, when they spin waterproof colonial webs and bask in sunshine.
Orange tip butterfly (Anthocharis cardamines) commonly seen on fens in the spring where its caterpillars feed on Cuckoo flower (Cardamine pratensis).

text.value: One of the largest moths found in wetlands and fens is the Emperor moth (Saturnia pavonia), which feeds on ling heather, bilberry and other wetland plants.

image.caption: Emperor moth caterpillar feeding on fen grasses at Coolagh Lakes on Lough Corrib Co. Galway.

text.value: The original extent of fens in the Republic of Ireland was 92,500 ha (Hammond Peatlands Map of 1979), 5% of the total land surface of Ireland. The most serious impact on fens has been their reclamation for agricultural land which involves drainage, fertilisation, reclamation and removal of peat. As a result 77% of Ireland’s fens have been lost to this use, leaving and estimated 22,000 ha suitable for conservation (Source: NPWS 2007).

Some Irish fen habitats are listed under Annex 1 of the European Habitats Directive because of their significant conservation importance (poor fens and non-calreous springs or not listed under the EU Habitats Directive). The four main fen types listed by the National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) for protection under the EU Habitats Directive are:
7140 Transition mires and quaking bogs
7120 Calcareous fens with Cladium mariscus and species of the Caricion davallianae
7220 Petrifying springs with tufa formation (Cratoneurion)
7230 Alkaline fens

title.value: EU Habitats Directive and Fen Conservation

text.value: 7230 Alkaline fens
Map showing the distribution of all 660 known and potential Alkaline fens in Ireland based on the Map of Irish Wetlands 2017.

Alkaline fens are typically calcareous basin or flush fen systems with extensive areas of species-rich small sedge communities. These fen systems are often a complex mosaic of habitats, with co-occuring tall sedge beds, reedbeds, wet grasslands, springs and open-water. This habitat requires a high water table, a calcareous, low nutrient water supply and minimal water level fluctuation. Low intensity mowing and/or grazing are also very important for maintaining species richness (Source: NPWS 2013).

image.caption: Map showing the 2013 Irish range (green and red 10km squares) as defined by NPWS for this habitat in Ireland.

text.value: 7120 Calcareous fens with Cladium mariscus and species of the Caricion davallianae * EU Priority habitat
Map showing the distribution of all 200 known and potential Cladium fens in Ireland based on the Map of Irish Wetlands 2017.

This fen type is often dominated by saw sedge (Cladium mariscus). Cladium fens occur in a variety of situations including fens found in valleys or depressions, floodplains, over-grown-ditches, extensive wet meadows, within tall reed beds, on the landward side of lakeshore communities, calcium rich flush areas in blanket bogs, dune slack areas, fens adjacent to raised and blanket bogs, in turloughs, wet hollows in machair and often in association with alkaline fen. The key ecological requirements are a high water table, a calcareous, low nutrient water supply and minimal water level fluctuation (Source: NPWS 2013).

image.caption: Map showing the 2013 Irish range (green and red 10km squares) as defined by NPWS for this habitat in Ireland.

text.value: 7220 Petrifying springs with tufa formation (Cratoneurion) * EU Priority habitat
Map showing the distribution of all 220 known and potential Calcareous or petrifying springs in Ireland based on the Map of Irish Wetlands 2017.

Petrifying Springs with Tufa Formation are defined as springs and seepages where tufa is actively deposited and where characteristic species of bryophytes are dominant or abundant (Source: NPWS 2013).

image.caption: Map showing the 2013 Irish range (green and red 10km squares) as defined by NPWS for this habitat in Ireland.

text.value: 7140 Transition mires and quaking bogs
Map showing the distribution of all 540 known and potential Transition mire and quaking bog sites in Ireland based on the Map of Irish Wetlands 2017.

Transition mires and quaking bogs are characterised by a broad range of physically unstable peat-forming vegetation communities floating on surface water. The key ecological requirements are thought to be a permanently high water level, remaining close to the peat surface all year, and minimal water level fluctuation (Source: NPWS 2013).

image.caption: Map showing the 2013 Irish range (green and red 10km squares) as defined by NPWS for this habitat in Ireland.

text.value: Under the EU Habitats Directive the National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) are obliged to complete a report every 7 years on the condition of designated habitats.
So how have we fared in the protection of Irish fens?

The assessments carried out to date in 2007 and again in 2013 found that since the introduction of the EU Habitats Directive in Ireland, no fen type of EU importance in Ireland (Transition mire, Alkaline fen, Cladium fen or Petrifying springs) is in good or favourable conservation status.

Fens (Transition mire, Alkaline fen and Cladium fen) were given a bad overall conservation assessment in these reports. This is primarily due to the on-going loss of habitat area, poor structure and function, and bad future prospects. Even Petrifying springs were assessed in 2013 as being in an overall inadequate state of conservation in Ireland.
The main drivers of the loss of fens include peat mining, drainage and reclamation for agriculture, infilling, fertiliser pollution and eutrophication.

Fens occur throughout the island of Ireland although their exact distribution remains unclear, as many fens have not been adequately surveyed to date. The map below shows the occurrence of all 1700 known and potential fens in Ireland based on information held in the Map of Irish Wetlands.

image.caption: The distribution of all potential fens in Ireland based on the Map of Irish Wetlands 2017.

text.value: Some of these fen sites have a variety of visitor facilities including parking, paths, boardwalks, exhibitions and information signs, that will help you enjoy a visit to these magical places, and learn more about fens, the wetlands in which they occur and their value to wildlife.

The map opposite shows a selection of fens included on the Map of Irish Wetlands, some of which you can explore further. By scrolling down you will learn more about these fen sites and what to see there. The description will tell you the fen types you can see at each location - in some cases a site can have more than one fen type present.
Visit wetlands safely and please follow our code of conduct.
* Take only photos and leave only footprints
* Never collect rare or endangered species
* Please ask permission before entering or crossing private land
* Keep to formed paths
* Please take care with fire, and smoke only in designated areas
* Leaving your dog at home, or keep it on a leash
* Be aware of potential safety issues and do not visit wetlands alone
Habitats: Poor fen and flushes

image.caption: Bottle sedge (Carex rostrata) flush in boggy upland terrain.

text.value: This site is a complex of upland areas in Co. Wicklow and Dublin. The dominant habitats in the Wicklow National Park are heath, blanket bog, cutaway bog, acid lakes, poor fen and flushes, and wet grassland.
Full visitor facilities are located in Glendalough. Limited parking at entrance to Kippure transmitter. No formal paths. Further info: Wicklow Mountains Park

title.value: Wicklow National Park, Cos Dublin and Wicklow

text.value: Habitats: Poor fen and flushes and Transition mire

image.caption: Poor fen community with abundant Bog bean beside a bog lake on Eshbrack.

text.value: Eshbrack Bog is an extensive upland area which includes significant areas of blanket bog, with cutover and regenerating bog and wet heath areas. The site includes a number of small flushed areas and bog lakes with marginal poor fen, transition mire and alkaline fen communities. Located on the Co. Monaghan and Cos. Fermanagh and Tyrone border. The point where the three counties meet, which is also in the Sliabh Beagh, is referred to as "Three County Hollow". The area is designated as a Ramsar site and Special Protection Area for birds.
Parking, extensive walking trails (Sliabh Beagh Way), and picnic areas.
Habitats: Poor fen and flushes

image.caption: Large poor fen flush in blanket bog landscape, Co. Mayo.

text.value: Extensive area of lowland blanket bog with a remarkably dense network of pools and small acidic lakes. The natural drainage network of valleys and flushes are floristically rich owing to an absence of burning and grazing. Spring-fed species-rich flushes are a significant feature of this site and occur throughout the bog complex. Many of these flushes are very large. Some of these are iron- flushed, notably those at Brackloon Lough on the eastern margin of the site.
Access to this site is from forestry tracks to the west. No paths or formal walking routes. Rough terrain.

image.caption: Surface appearance of iron stained flush with Bottle sedge (Carex rostrata) and Bog bean (Menyanthes trifoliata).

text.value: Habitat: Transition mire or Quaking bog

image.caption: Artificial pond created near entrance to Fennor Bog.

text.value: Fennor Bog in Co. Waterford is a valley bog with willow scrub, transition mire and tussock sedge habitats. Over 200 species of plant, bird, insect and animal have been recorded on the site. Managed by Móin Fhionnúrach Development Association and Irish Peatland Conservation Council.
Visitor facilities at the site include parking, boardwalk, seating and information signs. Further info: IPCC - Fennor Bog

image.caption: Fennor Bog boardwalk, allowing easy access to the fen habitats on the site.

text.value: Habitat: Transition mire or Quaking Bog

image.caption: Transition mire vegetation with Reedmace at Killyneill.

text.value: Large transition mire site with Lesser tussock-sedge (Carex diandra) and some some poor fen and wet woodland areas. The site broken into a number of discrete compartments by the R213 road and a local road running east-west which intersect at Killyneill Cross Roads.
Privately owned area with limited access to this site. Limited parking, no formal paths. Rough terrain.

image.caption: Transition mire vegetation dominated by Lesser tussock-sedge (Carex diandra) on Killyneill.

text.value: Habitat: Transition mire or Quaking Bog

image.caption: Lesser tussock sedge (Carex diandra) transition mire at Cloonagh Bog, Co. Sligo.

text.value: This is a large site, which has been cut away in the past and now is dominated by transition mire flora which is species rich. A spring is found within the site which appears to be calcareous but was not tufa forming. This is a good example of a coastal Lesser tussock-sedge (Carex diandra) transition mire.
Privately owned area with limited access to this site. Limited parking, no formal paths. Rough terrain.

image.caption: Ophioglossum vulgatum, commonly known as Adder's-tongue, a primitive member of the fern family on Cloonagh Bog.

text.value: Habitat: Alkaline fen and Cladium fen

image.caption: Black bog rush (Schoenus nigricans) fen growing on cutover bog at Scragh Bog.

text.value: Scragh Bog Co. Westmeath is a quaking fen that lies in a linear depression between hills covered by limestone drift. It is essentially a water body covered by a floating mat of vegetation. The best example in Ireland of the transition from alkaline fen to acidic raised bog. It contains a large number of uncommon plants and insects which are rare in Europe. The bog was purchased by the Irish Peatland Conservation Council with funds generously provided by the Dutch Foundation for the Conservation of Irish Bogs.
Parking, information sign, boardwalk and elevated viewing platform. Further info: Scragh Bog

image.caption: Visitor boardwalk and observation platform at Scragh Bog.

text.value: Habitat: Secondary alkaline fen on cutover bog

image.caption: Black bog rush (Schoenus nigricans) fen growing on abandoned cutover bog at Killaun Bog.

text.value: Killaun Bog in Co. Offaly is an area of intact raised bog and cutover bog which has become recolonised by birch woodland and a variety of wetland and rich fen communities in cut out bog holes. Killaun is managed by Bord na Móna and the Birr Community School Trust.
Visitor facilities include a boardwalk. Parking facilities are limited and located at the eastern site entrance.

image.caption: Boardwalk at Killaun bog, an ideal way to see fen communities while keeping your wet dry.

text.value: Habitat: Alkaline fen in dune slack

image.caption: Dune slack area on North Bull island with scattered alder trees.

text.value: The North Bull Island Co. Dublin is a well-developed sand dune, saltmarsh and mudflats system. The North Bull Island is managed by Dublin City Council. The coastal wetlands attract a wide variety of water birds. About 1 km from the northern tip of the island, a large dune slack occurs with a rich fen flora. Spring and summer are ideal time to see butterflies and the rich flora of the site.
Parking, visitor centre and unpaved walking tracks through dune and dune slack areas.
Habitat: Alkaline fen, Cladium fen and calcareous springs

image.caption: Saw sedge (Cladium mariscus) fen beside boardwalk on Pollardstown Fen.

text.value: Pollardstown fen is the largest remaining spring-fed fen in Ireland located near Newbridge in Co. Kildare. Habitats include semi-natural fen including alkaline fen, Cladium fen and calcareous springs, damp grassland, woodland, and open water. Pollardstown Fen is of international importance, as this type of system is now rare in Ireland and Western Europe. In addition, it contains a number of rare vegetation types and invertebrate fauna.
Car park, boardwalk and information signs. Further info: Pollardstown Fen

image.caption: Visitor boardwalk through Black bog rush (Schoenus nigricans) fen areas on Pollardstown fen.

text.value: Habitat: Alkaline fen and Cladium fen

image.caption: Saw sedge (Cladium mariscus) fen with scattered willow trees at East Coast Nature Reserve.

text.value: The East Coast Nature Reserve covers 92ha. It forms part of the extensive Murrough Wetlands in Co. Wicklow. The reserve includes a variety of habitats, including alkaline and Cladium fen, wet grasslands and birch woodland, which can all be explored on foot through marked walking trails and observation hides. The reserve is rich in wild flowers, insects and birds. The different habitats are managed for a variety of species that prefer the wet grassland areas which are seasonally flooded to attract wintering wildfowl, or the woodland glades opened up for butterflies.
Car park, boardwalk, bird hides and information signs. Further info: East Coast Nature Reserve

image.caption: Extensive areas of Black bog rush (Schoenus nigricans) fen also occur at the East Coast Nature Reserve.

title.value: East Coast Nature Reserve, Co. Wicklow

text.value: Habitat: Alkaline fen and Cladium fen

image.caption: View of Saw sedge (Cladium mariscus) fen vegetation along the northern shore of Summerhill Lough, with Willow and Alder wet woodland inland of the fen zone.

text.value: The Kilroosky bog cluster includes 5 sub-sites with wetland interest: Ramages Lough, Kilroosky Lough, Burdautien Lough, Dummy’s Lough and Summerhill Lough which are oligotrophic alkaline lakes, with the exception of Ramages Lough which is a large reed bed area. These lakes have fringing reed bed vegetation with Cladium fen and smaller areas of alkaline fen vegetation behind the reed zone.
Limited parking facilities, rough tracks and fishing platforms.
Habitat: Calcareous springs

image.caption: Calcareous spring with tufa formation situated in the coastal spray zone in north Co. Dublin.

text.value: Series of coastal calcareous springs with tufa build up, on cliffs above the high water mark. The moss Palustriella commutata is plentiful on the gently sloping upper part of the cascade, but most of the sheer face is occupied by Eucladium verticillatum. At some locations at the base of the cascade, pebbles from the beach have become incorporated into the rapidly forming tufa.
Park at Loughshinny harbour. Beach walk over rocky terrain.

title.value: Loughshinny to Skerries Coast Springs, Co. Dublin

text.value: Habitat: Calcareous springs

image.caption: Calcareous spring with tufa formation situated in the coastal spray zone at Malin Beg.

text.value: Series of coastal calcareous springs with tufa build up, on cliffs above the high water mark. The moss Palustriella commutata is plentiful on the gently sloping upper parts of the cascade.
Car park, stepped path down to beach and information signs.

image.caption: Calcareous spring with tufa formation on rock cliff face at Malin Beg.

text.value: Habitat: Calcareous springs

image.caption: Large tufa spring deposits at Knocknarea Mountain.

text.value: A series of large tufa springs occur at Knocknarea Mountain Co. Sligo. The petrifying springs are found along a sheer limestone rock face within the Knocknarea Glen. The tufa forming petrifying springs area at least 2m tall in most parts and form large cylindrical columns or cones. These are often topped by ferns or ivy with the face of the tufa supporting rich moss layer with scattered Herb-robert or Meadowsweet plants. In some cases hanging stalactites of tufa are matched at the base by stalagmite like structures. In other cases the tufa has broken off in block like structures.
Limited car parking, rough walking path.

image.caption: Tufa spring forming large cylindrical columns or cones at Knocknarea Mountain.

text.value: Habitat: Poor fen and flush, non-calcareous springs

image.caption: Sphagnum dominated spring head community in wet heath in the Sheeffrey Hills.

text.value: The Mweelrea/Sheeffry/Erriff Complex covers a large area of the scenic hills of south Mayo. The site is a candidate SAC selected for active blanket bog and petrifying springs, while areas of transition mire and alkaline fen also occur. Sphagnum spring head, non-calcareous flush occur on the mid slopes of the valley among wet heath and blanket bog vegetation.
Privately owned area with limited access to this site. Limited parking, hill walking routes. Rough terrain.
Habitat: Non-calcareous springs

image.caption: Anthelia spring community on flushed bare rock face in the Sheeffrey mountain.

text.value: The Mweelrea/Sheeffry/Erriff Complex covers a large area of the scenic hills of south Mayo. The site is a candidate SAC selected for active blanket bog and petrifying springs, while areas of transition mire and alkaline fen also occur. Anthelia julacea spring community in the Sheefrey Hills Co. Mayo. This non-calcareous spring community is dominated by the grey liverwort Anthelia julacea. The community thrives at higher altitude, where rock surfaces are fed by steady trickle of acid and oligotrophic (nutrient poor) waters.
Privately owned area with limited access to this site. Limited parking, hill walking routes. Rough terrain.
Habitat: Non-calcareous springs

image.caption: Dichodontium palustre (previously Dicranella palustris) non-calcareous flush at Slieve League.

text.value: Along the southern side of the site are very steep, often precipitous slopes and sea-cliffs which are among the highest in Europe (590m O.D.), rising from the sea almost to the summit of Slieve League. A heathy vegetation of Ling Heather (Calluna vulgaris) dominates over much of the area. Non-calcareous spring communities occurs in the base of the valley on rocky cliffs.
Car park and information signs short distance to the west. Rough terrain.

image.caption: Dichodontium palustre with Bryum pseudotriquetrum and  Scapania undulata in non-calcareous spring at Slieve League.
